text:
Hey, everyone.
I'm here in New York City

celebrating
the 25th anniversary

of "The Lion King"
on Broadway.

Broadway is
the world's famous home

to some of the biggest
plays and musicals.

This is the stage door,
where the actors,

hair and makeup, everyone
involved in the production

enters the theatre.
Let's go.

I'm so excited to be back
on this stage.

When I was ten years old,
I played young Nala.
And now I get to speak

with the current cast
and production

all about this amazing show's
25 years on Broadway.

I want to know what your
favorite part of "Lion King" is.

I definitely love seeing
the audience members
enjoying the show.

It's such an incredible visual
and an amazing story.

Why do you think
the show is so loved?
The storytelling is so real.

There's loss, but then there's
also the love of community

- and parental love. 
- It really is relatable

and you can see yourself
in some characters.

It's so incredible,
from the costumes

to all the puppets,
to the way everything works.

Kyliegh:
I see we have the masks here.

Could you tell me
a bit about those?

- Would you like to try it on?
- Yes, please.

Oh, it's a lot lighter
than I thought.

Every single one of our masks
has a custom-made head mount

so that it fits the performer
and they can dance

and jump and run
and the mask doesn't come off.

I like the difference
between the lioness mask

and Mufasa's mask
versus Scar's,

- which is a lot darker. 
- This is Zazu.
He's got strings and pulleys,

and mechanisms
that operate his eyes,
his mouth, and his neck.

He can be so expressive.
Would you like to try it?
Yes, please. Oh, my gosh!

This is like my childhood
dream come true.

"I'm the king's majordomo.
Squawk!"

Every single one
of his feathers is hand cut

and stitched on, and they're
all quilted onto his body.

There's a lot of time
that goes into all the puppets.

"I'm going to give you
a little kiss. Mwah!"

- ♪ The circle of life ♪ 
- Behind us is Pride Rock.

Would you mind telling us
how it works?
With the press of a button,

Pride Rock rises
from the stage,

and it grows,
and the audience is amazed.

The iconic-- the staple
of "Lion King."

Celebrate 25 years of
"The Lion King" on Broadway.
Parents can visit LionKing.com
for ticket information.
( vocalizing )
